WHAT.TITLE: Va?
WHAT.BODY:
Det här verktyget introducerar maskininlärning genom att erbjuda praktiska erfarenheter i att träna maskininlärningssystem och bygga saker med dem.

Det tillhandahåller en lättanvänd och handledd miljö för att träna maskininlärningsmodeller som klassificerar text, tal och känner igen bilder.

Det här bygger på existerande ansträngningar att introducera och lära ut programmering till barn, genom att lägga till de här modellerna i Scratch (en programmeringsplattform som är vida använd), vilket tillåter barn att skapa projekt och bygga spel med maskininlärningsmodellerna som de har tränat.

För att lära dig mer, kolla på:

WHY.TITLE: Varför?
WHY.BODY:
Maskininlärning finns överallt omkring oss. Alla använder vi maskininlärningssystem varje dag; som t.ex. skräpfilter, rekommendationsmotorer, översättningstjänster, chat-botar och digitala assistenter, sökmotorer och system för att upptäcka bedrägeri.

Det kommer inom kort att vara normalt att maskininlärningssystem kör våra bilar, och hjälper läkare att diagnosticera och behandla sjukdomar.

Det är viktigt att barn är medvetna om hur vår värld fungerar. Det bästa sättet att förstå möjligheterna och riskerna är att vara förmögna att bygga med denna teknologin själva.

För att lära dig mer, läs: 'Introducing Machine Learning to kids'

TECH.TITLE: Teknik
TECH.BODY:
Verktyget är helt och hållet webb-baserat och kräver ingen installation eller komplicerad konfiguration för att användas.

Det utformades för att användas i klassrum av skolor och frivilliga kodningsgrupper för barn, och tillhandahåller en admin-sida för lärare eller grupphandledare för att hantera och administrera tillgång för deras elever.

Det utvecklas av Dale Lane och använder API:er från IBM Watson Developer Cloud.

PRETRAINED.BODY: Pre-trained models are also provided for students to use in their projects. These advanced models enable projects that might otherwise be too complex for students to train for themselves, and provide useful hands-on insights into some of the other things that machine learning can do.

FURTHER.TITLE: Further learning
FURTHER.BODY:
Machine Learning for Kids is a useful tool for introducing children to how ML systems are trained, how they are used, and some of the real-world implications of AI applications.

For additional teaching and learning resources, including teaching the internals of ML systems, please see:

LINKS.TITLE: Educational AI resources for children
LINKS.INTRO: This page is a list of further tools and resources for introducing children to artificial intelligence.

ECRAFT2LEARN.BODY1: Ken Kahn has created resources to allow beginners to create AI programs in Snap! (a visual programming environment similar to Scratch).
ECRAFT2LEARN.BODY2: While I've focused on explaining how AI systems are trained and behave (and the real-world implications), eCraft2Learn has fantastic resources that dive deep into how ML systems actually work.
ECRAFT2LEARN.BODY3: The neural net Tic Tac Toe project is particularly fascinating, allowing students to experiment with hyperparameters from Snap.

STEMLEARNING.BODY1: STEM Learning and the UK Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy have created resources for teaching the principles of artificial intelligence.
STEMLEARNING.BODY2: These resources include Machine Learning for Kids projects, supplemented with teaching notes, presentation materials, prompt cards, and practical “unplugged” activities

RASPBERRYPI.BODY1: The Raspberry Pi Foundation provides resources for Code Clubs, with step-by-step instructions for a variety of creative projects.
RASPBERRYPI.BODY2: Their machine learning pathway includes a variety of projects from Machine Learning for Kids.

APPSFORGOOD.BODY1: Apps for Good are a UK-based not-for-profit that creates resources for teaching technology subjects, that they make freely available to schools.
APPSFORGOOD.BODY2: Their Machine Learning course uses Machine Learning for Kids, and supplements it with a range of additional materials like schemes of work, lesson plans, student workbooks, presentations and more. It makes it easy for schools to deliver ML lessons that put the coding exercises in context.

AIFAMILYCHALLENGE.BODY1: The AI Family Challenge is a free, hands-on AI education program for families. They use Machine Learning for Kids, and supplement it with a lot of additional support, such as technical coaches and mentors, a structured lesson plan and supporting videos.
AIFAMILYCHALLENGE.BODY2: The program is based around a competition that challenges children to think of their own AI project ideas, with the support of their families and technical mentors.

MAGENTADEMOS.BODY1: Online toys that demonstrate different aspects of machine learning, using TensorFlow.js

AIINSCHOOLS.BODY1: The AIinSchools programme provides a free lesson plan for teachers to explain AI to Year 9 (aged 13-14).
AIINSCHOOLS.BODY2: It includes both unplugged classroom activities, and programming activities for training neural networks on GPUs running on AWS.

TEENSINAI.BODY1: Teens in AI use a combination of hackathons, accelerators and bootcamps to support young people aged 12-18 to explore AI.

AI4ALL.BODY1: AI4ALL run summer camps for high school students in the US that give a detailed technical introduction to AI.

CALYPSO.BODY1: Students with programmable Cozmo robots can use the Calypso programming framework to get a hands-on way to experience AI by experimenting with techniques like computer vision and speech recognition.

AIINABOX.BODY1: AI-in-a-Box is a bundle of robots, accessories and teaching resources. The kit can be used to teach projects that cover topics like visual recognition, facial recognition, speech generation and speech recognition.

GOOGLEEXPERIMENTS.BODY1: Simple online experiments to start exploring machine learning, through pictures, drawings, language, and music.

TYPES.LABEL: Känna igen

EXPLAINTYPES.NOTICE: What is the difference between "images" and "images beta" ?
EXPLAINTYPES.NOTES_1: If you choose "images" your machine learning model will be trained on cloud servers.
EXPLAINTYPES.NOTES_2: If you choose "images beta" your machine learning model will be trained on your own computer.
EXPLAINTYPES.NOTES_4: It can be used for projects in Scratch, App Inventor, or Python.
EXPLAINTYPES.NOTES_5: It doesn't matter if your computer is slow, as the model is trained in the cloud.
EXPLAINTYPES.NOTES_6: But, it takes minutes to train while you wait for your turn on the cloud server.
EXPLAINTYPES.NOTES_7: "images beta" is good because:
EXPLAINTYPES.NOTES_8: It can be much quicker to train, because you don't have to wait for your turn on the cloud server.
EXPLAINTYPES.NOTES_9: But, it can only be used for Scratch projects.

DATASETS.TITLE: Copy a machine learning project template

INTRO.INTRO_1: You can create new machine learning project based on one of these templates.
INTRO.INTRO_2: Each one includes a set of training data that has been collected for you to help you get started quickly.
INTRO.INTRO_3: You will be able to make changes to the training data if you like, or you can go straight to training a machine learning model with it.

MORE.TITLE: Other data sets
MORE.SUMMARY: What other data sets would you like to see?
MORE.DESCRIPTION: Have you got an idea for a data set you'd like to see available here? Or do you have a data set that you'd like to contribute? Please get in touch!

TITANIC.TITLE: Titanic survivors
TITANIC.DESCRIPTION: On 15th April 1912, the RMS Titanic hit an iceberg and sank, killing over 1500 of the passengers and crew. This project includes personal data about hundreds of the passengers. You can use this to train a machine learning model that, if you give it a description of a passenger, can learn to predict the likelihood that they would have survived.
TITANIC.DETAILS:
The 'ticket class' field is a number indicating the type of ticket for the passenger: first class (1), second class (2), or third class (3). 
The 'gender' field is whether the passenger was 'male' or 'female'. 
The 'age' field is the age of the passenger. 
The 'sibl. sp.' is the number of brothers or sisters (siblings) the passenger had on board if they were a child, or the number of husbands or wives (spouses) the passenger had on board if they were an adult. 
The 'par. ch.' field is the number of parents the passenger had on board if they were a child, or the number of children the passenger had on board if they were an adult. 
The 'ticket fare' field is how much they paid for their ticket. 
The 'embarked' field is where they got on board the Titanic, either Cherbourg, Queenstown or Southampton.

CATSANDDOGS.TITLE: Cats and Dogs
CATSANDDOGS.SUMMARY: Recognize photos of cats vs dogs
CATSANDDOGS.DESCRIPTION: Training a machine learning model to recognise photos of cats and dogs is a good simple introduction to image recognition.
CATSANDDOGS.DETAILS: This training dataset of photos from Wikimedia Commons is a good starting set for building your own training data of animal photos

UKNEWSPAPERS.TITLE: UK Newspaper Headlines
UKNEWSPAPERS.SUMMARY: Recognize the use of language in newspaper headlines
UKNEWSPAPERS.DESCRIPTION: Different newspapers use language in different ways. This project includes the main front page headline from four UK newspapers. You can use this to train a machine learning model that can learn to predict the most likely newspaper that a new headline is probably from.
UKNEWSPAPERS.DETAILS: This training dataset includes headlines from the Daily Mail, the Daily Telegraph, the Independent, and The Guardian

PHISHING.TITLE: Phishing
PHISHING.SUMMARY: Predict if a link is a phishing link
PHISHING.DESCRIPTION: Phishing is when a website tries to trick you into giving up sensitive information, by sending you a link to a fake website disguised like a trustworthy one. You can use this to train a machine learning model that can predict if a web address is a real link, or a phishing link to a fake website.
PHISHING.DETAILS:
This training dataset includes attributes of five hundred legitimate web addresses, and five hundred phishing links.

The 'address type' field is 'IP addr' if the link has a numeric IP address like '104.20.74.246' or 'DNS name' if the link has a name-based address like 'machinelearningforkids.co.uk'. 
The 'url length' field groups the training addresses by how long they are. 
The 'shortening' field is 'yes' if the web address uses a shortening service like TinyURL or bit.ly, or 'no' if it doesn't. 
The 'includes @' field is 'yes' if the web address includes an @ symbol, or 'no' if it doesn't. 
The 'port number' field is 'standard' if the web address uses a standard port number like 80 or 443, or 'non-std' if it uses something different. 
The 'domain age' field groups addresses by how long ago the web address in the address was registered. 
The 'redirects' field groups the training addresses by the number of times a web browser is sent to a different address before reaching a final page. 
The 'domain reg' field is 'expiring' if the registration for the web address domain name expires within a year.

NOUGHTSANDCROSSES.SUMMARY: Learn how to play a game
NOUGHTSANDCROSSES.DESCRIPTION: Train a machine learning model to play noughts and crosses, by collecting examples of moves that the computer can use to learn how to predict the best move to make next.
NOUGHTSANDCROSSES.DETAILS: This is an empty template to help you collect your own training data. For instructions on how to use it, download 'Noughts and Crosses' from Worksheets

TOPTRUMPS.TITLE: Kings & Queens Top Trumps
TOPTRUMPS.SUMMARY: Learn how to play a game
TOPTRUMPS.DESCRIPTION: Train a machine learning model to play a Top Trumps game based on English Kings and Queens, by collecting examples of moves that the computer can use to learn how to predict which value to choose.
TOPTRUMPS.DETAILS: This is an empty template to help you collect your own training data. For instructions on how to use it, download 'Top Trumps' from Worksheets.

SONGLYRICS.TITLE: Song lyrics
SONGLYRICS.DESCRIPTION: Train a machine learning model to recognize the type of song based on it's lyrics
SONGLYRICS.DETAILS: This training dataset includes 140 lines from song lyrics - half from children's songs and half from Top 40 songs. It is a good starting set for training a machine learning model to recognize different uses of language.

IDLE.NOLABELS: The next step is to go to the Train page. Add some labels for each of the things that you want to teach the computer to be able to recognise.

ONELABEL.EXPLANATION: You've only said one thing that you want the computer to be able to recognise: {{ label }}

ONELABEL.NO:
No?
Go back to the Train page.
Add more labels for each of the things that you want to teach the computer to be able to recognise.
ONELABEL.YES:
Yes?
You need to do a little more work first.
For the computer to be able to learn how to recognise "{{ label }}", you need to give it some examples of things that aren't {{ label }}.
Go back to the Train page and create a new label for examples of things that aren't {{ label }}. You could call it "not-{{ label }}".

LABELS.NO_DATA: The next step is to go to the Train page. Add examples for each of the labels.

MORE_EXAMPLES.YOU: Go back to the Train page and collect more examples for each of the labels.

MORE_DATA.MORE_IS_BETTER: The more you can get, the better it should learn, but you need at least {{ minimumExamples }} examples of each as an absolute minimum.

QUIZ.TITLE: Quiz-dags!
QUIZ.INTROQUESTION: Medan du väntar på att modellen att avsluta träningen kan du försöka svara på den här frågan.
QUIZ.PREVIOUSLY_ATTEMPTED: You've seen this one before - let's see if you remember what the right answer is this time!
QUIZ.INCORRECT_ANSWER: No, sorry. The correct answer is shown above.

QUESTION_1.QUESTION: In general, what will help machines to learn better?
QUESTION_1.NOTES_1: That isn't the only thing that has an effect. But in general, the more examples it has to learn from, the better it should learn.

QUESTION_2.QUESTION: Which of these would probably be best for training a computer to recognise a photo of an apple?
QUESTION_2.ANSWER_2: Varied photos of different types of apples in different places
QUESTION_2.ANSWER_4: Very, very similar photos of the same apple in the same place
QUESTION_2.NOTES_1: The more varied the examples you can collect, the more the system can learn about how to recognise different pictures of an apple.
QUESTION_2.NOTES_2: If every example you give it is the same apple on the same brown wooden table, it might learn that something is only an apple if it's on a brown wooden table.

QUESTION_3.QUESTION: Which of these would be a good use of machine learning?
QUESTION_3.ANSWER_2: Recognising if an email is spam
QUESTION_3.ANSWER_3: Counting the number of times a button is pressed
QUESTION_3.NOTES_1: Spam filters are a good example of machine learning.
QUESTION_3.NOTES_2: With enough examples of legitimate emails, and enough examples of spam emails, a computer can start to learn how to recognise a spam email.

QUESTION_4.QUESTION: Which of these is NOT a good use of machine learning?
QUESTION_4.ANSWER_1: Sentiment analysis - recognising the mood, tone or emotion in text
QUESTION_4.ANSWER_2: Translating text from one language to another
QUESTION_4.ANSWER_3: Face recognition - recognising a face in a photo and identifying who it is
QUESTION_4.ANSWER_5: Calculating the cost of something in different countries based on exchange rates
QUESTION_4.ANSWER_6: Recommending a movie based on films you've watched before
QUESTION_4.NOTES_1: Tasks that involve following rules which can be worked out are not a good use for machine learning.
QUESTION_4.NOTES_2: A computer isn't going to learn how to apply an exchange rate from examples - we can just tell it what to do.

QUESTION_5.QUESTION: Which of these would be more likely to be successful?
QUESTION_5.ANSWER_1: Collect a small set of examples, train a system, test to see how good it is. Add more examples, train again, and then test again. Repeat until it gets good enough.
QUESTION_5.ANSWER_2: More examples is better, so decide you must need millions of examples. Start collecting a massive set of examples, and spend months collecting more and more and more.
QUESTION_5.NOTES_1: More examples is generally better, but be practical.
QUESTION_5.NOTES_2: Pragmatism is important. Regular testing is useful to let you know how things are going, and help you know when you've done enough.
QUESTION_5.NOTES_3: When you've only got ten examples, another ten examples will probably make a huge difference.
QUESTION_5.NOTES_4: When you've got 100,000 examples, another ten examples probably won't have a noticeable impact.

QUESTION_6.QUESTION: Which of these statements is correct?
QUESTION_6.ANSWER_1: Machine learning is a technique where computers can be trained to perform tasks instead of needing to be given an explicit set of steps to follow
QUESTION_6.ANSWER_3: Machine learning means we don't need to think about problems any more because computers will think for us
QUESTION_6.ANSWER_4: Machine learning has replaced the need for us to learn how to code
QUESTION_6.ANSWER_5: Machine learning can only be done on massive supercomputers

QUESTION_7.QUESTION: A machine learning system trained to recognise pictures with a tree in should be good at which of the following tasks:
QUESTION_7.ANSWER_2: Recognising the emotion in a piece of writing
QUESTION_7.NOTES_1: Machine learning does not mean computers magically learn to do everything.
QUESTION_7.NOTES_2: It means they learn how to do a specific task by being shown examples of that specific task.
QUESTION_7.NOTES_3: If you want it to do something else, you need to train it to do that as well, by giving it examples of that.

QUESTION_8.QUESTION: Alice and Bob both want to train a machine learning system to recognise if text is happy/positive or sad/negative. Which of them will probably train the best system?
QUESTION_8.ANSWER_1: Alice. She has collected 10 varied examples of happy text, and 10 varied examples of sad text
QUESTION_8.ANSWER_2: Bob. He has collected 1000 examples of happy writing and 10 examples of sad writing
QUESTION_8.NOTES_1: Collecting a roughly similar number of examples for each label is a useful technique.
QUESTION_8.NOTES_2: If nearly every example of writing you train a system with is happy, you might end up training the system to assume that sad writing is very unlikely, and that it should assume happy more often.
QUESTION_8.NOTES_4: But, you might want it to do this.
QUESTION_8.NOTES_5: If you're training a system to recognise text where text is happy 98% of the time, training it with that realistic experience might be worth a try.

QUESTION_9.QUESTION: Advanced machine learning technology will always give correct answers. Incorrect answers mean the machine learning technology isn't very good
QUESTION_9.NOTES_3: The technology and algorithms are important. BUT machine learning systems are only as accurate and reliable as the training they are given.
QUESTION_9.NOTES_4: Simple machine learning algorithms with a lot of high quality training can do better than the most advanced machine learning algorithms with a small amount of poor quality training.

QUESTION_10.QUESTION: How can you make sure your collection of animal pictures is good quality for training a machine and doesn't contain human mistakes?
QUESTION_10.ANSWER_1: Manually inspect all of the pictures of animals yourself and make sure you agree with all of the labels
QUESTION_10.ANSWER_2: Ask lots of people to label all the images and keep the training labels that people generally agree on
QUESTION_10.ANSWER_3: Trick question! Humans are always right - machines make mistakes!
QUESTION_10.NOTES_1: Even humans make mistakes and you won't always have time to double check all the training data!
QUESTION_10.NOTES_2: If the task is tricky it can be a good idea to get more than one person to label each image and keep the label that the most humans agree is the right one.

QUESTION_11.QUESTION: A machine trained to identify pictures of "food" or "not food" gives inconsistent results for sandwiches, often putting them in the "not food" class. Which of the following could explain that?
QUESTION_11.ANSWER_1: The human who trained the system doesn't like sandwiches and didn't put any in the training data
QUESTION_11.ANSWER_2: The machine has to be in the right mood for a sandwich so it changes its mind a lot
QUESTION_11.ANSWER_3: Sandwiches are not food. The system is right to be unsure
QUESTION_11.NOTES_1: Machine learning models can only learn from the examples we show them.
QUESTION_11.NOTES_2: It is very easy for humans to accidentally introduce their likes and dislikes into machine learning models so we should be very careful about what training data we use.

QUESTION_12.QUESTION: Which of the following best describes unsupervised learning?
QUESTION_12.ANSWER_1: Writing a program that contains lots of if/else statements to determine the result
QUESTION_12.ANSWER_2: A machine learning algorithm that uses unlabelled data and classifies it based on how similar one dataset is to another
QUESTION_12.ANSWER_3: A machine learning algorithm that uses labelled data and classifies it based on training from example input-output pairs
QUESTION_12.NOTES_1: Unsupervised learning is a type of machine learning, whereas only using if/else statements is not.
QUESTION_12.NOTES_2: Unsupervised learning algorithms are still trained, but the inputs that are given to it are not labelled or classified.
QUESTION_12.NOTES_3: If the data is labelled then this is what's known as supervised learning.

QUESTION_13.QUESTION: Without machine learning, it would be impossible for search engines such as Google to exist.
QUESTION_13.NOTES_1: Whilst many modern search engines do use machine learning, it is possible to create one without it. A basic search engine will just look for documents (web pages) that include the words the user searches for.

DESCRIBEMODEL.TITLE: Understand your machine learning model
DESCRIBEMODEL.TRYITOUT: Try out your machine learning model to see how it uses the decision tree to make predictions

EXPLANATION.EXPL_1: The technique used to create your machine learning model is called a Decision Tree Classifier.
EXPLANATION.EXPL_2: This is not the only way to train a machine learning model. We're using it because it's very quick and easy to train, and it is one of the easiest techniques to understand. This page shows you the decision tree that was created based on the training examples that you have collected.
EXPLANATION.EXPL_3: When you test your model, the computer starts at the top of the tree, and follows a path until it reaches the bottom. The class at the bottom of the tree is the prediction that the machine learning model makes.
EXPLANATION.EXPL_4: At each box in the tree, it reads the test described at the top of the box. If your test values pass the test described in the box, it follows the arrow to the left. If it doesn't pass the test, it follows the arrow to the right.
EXPLANATION.EXPL_5: The samples shown in each box tells you how many examples in your training data matches that part of the decision tree.
EXPLANATION.EXPL_6: The value shown in each box tells you how many examples in your training data passed the test shown at the top (following the left arrow) and how many examples didn't pass the test at the top (following the right arrow).

ERRORS.NUMBERSONLY: Only machine learning models for numbers projects can be described

DESCRIBETEXTMODEL.ZOOM: Use these controls to zoom in on the diagrams

ERRORS.TEXTONLY: Only neural networks for text projects can be described

DESCRIBETEXTMODEL.MOREINFO: for more detail, try searching for:

PAGE1.TITLE: neural networks
PAGE1.TEXT1: The type of machine learning model you trained in this project is called a neural network.
PAGE1.TEXT2: The next few pages will explain how your model was created.
PAGE1.TEXT3: These diagrams aren't an exact description of your model. Your model is larger and more complicated, but these diagrams are easier to explain.

PAGE2.TITLE: deep learning
PAGE2.TEXT1: The model is made of nodes, arranged in vertical layers.
PAGE2.TEXT2: Models with a lot of layers are described as deep.
PAGE2.TEXT3: Deep models can give better results, but take longer to train.

PAGE3.TITLE: input layer
PAGE3.TEXT1: Let's start with one of the training examples used to create your model.
PAGE3.TEXT2: Your training example is shown as input on the left.

PAGE4.TITLE: encoding
PAGE4.TEXT1: To use your training example to train the model, first the text needs to be turned into a series of numbers.
PAGE4.TEXT2: There are lots of ways to do this.
PAGE4.TEXT3: If you build your own machine learning model, you need to choose a way that works well for your particular project.

PAGE5.TITLE: bag of words
PAGE5.TEXT1: One way of turning your text into numbers is to make each number a count of how many times a word is included.

PAGE6.TITLE: feature extraction
PAGE6.TEXT1: There are other things you can count. Things that are helpful to count depend on the project you are doing, and what you want your model to learn to recognize patterns in.
PAGE6.TEXT2: Counting things is quick and simple, but not as good for projects where the order of words is important.

PAGE7.TITLE: word embeddings
PAGE7.TEXT1: If you build your own machine learning model, you need to choose the method for turning text into numbers.
PAGE7.TEXT2: Your model used a more complicated technique that does include the order of words in the text.

PAGE8.TITLE: hidden layer
PAGE8.TEXT1: The numbers from the input layer go into sums that calculate values for the nodes in the next layer.
PAGE8.TEXT2: The lines on the diagram show which input values are used to calculate which values in the next layer.

PAGE9.TITLE: activation functions
PAGE9.TEXT1: There are lots of different types of calculation you can use. Not every node in the model has to use the same calculation.
PAGE9.TEXT2: If you build your own machine learning model, you need to choose which equations to use for each node.
PAGE9.TEXT3: The functions to use for each node in your model were chosen for you.

PAGE10.TITLE: weight
PAGE10.TEXT1: Each line in the diagram has a weight number that can be used in the sum.
PAGE10.TEXT2: Training the model is how we work out the best number to put on each line, as you'll see in a moment.

PAGE11.TITLE: bias
PAGE11.TEXT1: Each node in the diagram has a bias number that is used in the sum as well.
PAGE11.TEXT2: Training the model is also how we work out the right bias number, as you'll see in a moment.
PAGE11.TEXT3: Try to work out what you think the value for this node will be.

PAGE12.TITLE: activation functions
PAGE12.TEXT1: This is a common function used in neural networks.
PAGE12.TEXT2: Each input value is multiplied by the value for the line that connected it. These are all added together. Then added to the value for the node itself.

PAGE13.TITLE: activation functions
PAGE13.TEXT1: Each node has its own bias value.
PAGE13.TEXT2: Each line has its own weight value.

PAGE14.TITLE: hidden layers
PAGE14.TEXT1: Each node in the model can use different equations.
PAGE14.TEXT2: If you build your own machine learning model, you need to choose:
PAGE14.LIST2: how many nodes to put in each layer
PAGE14.LIST3: which functions to use for each node

PAGE15.TITLE: hidden layer
PAGE15.TEXT1: This continues through the rest of the model.
PAGE15.TEXT2: The number of layers, the number of nodes in each layer, and the functions to use for each node in your model were all chosen for you.

PAGE16.TITLE: output layer
PAGE16.TEXT1: The final layer gives the machine learning model's prediction.
PAGE16.TEXT2: There is a node for each bucket you added to your training data.

PAGE17.TITLE: loss function
PAGE17.TEXT1: The prediction is compared with the correct answer (the training bucket you put this example in).
PAGE17.TEXT2: The difference is described as the error rate, and tells us how well the machine learning model is doing at this stage of the training.

PAGE18.TITLE: back propagation
PAGE18.TEXT1: The error rate is used to go backwards through the layers and nudge the numbers for each of the lines and nodes.
PAGE18.TEXT2: Each weight and bias number is increased a little bit or decreased a little bit, depending on what would've made the error rate a little smaller.

PAGE19.TITLE: neural networks
PAGE19.TEXT1: Next, this is all done over again, with another of your training examples.

PAGE20.TITLE: encoding
PAGE20.TEXT1: Remember, the first step is turning the example text into numbers.
PAGE20.TEXT2: Counting things that are in the text is an easy way to do it, but there are more complicated ways to do it if the order of words is important.
PAGE20.TEXT3: The method for your model was chosen for you.

PAGE21.TITLE: hidden layer
PAGE21.TEXT1: Remember, nodes in the middle of the model represent sums that are done using the input numbers.
PAGE21.TEXT2: Different calculations can be chosen for each node.

PAGE22.TITLE: activation functions
PAGE22.TEXT1: Remember, the calculations use numbers from the nodes on the left that are connected to it, as well as the numbers for the lines that connect them.

PAGE23.TITLE: activation functions
PAGE23.TEXT1: The calculations also use a bias number for the node itself.

PAGE24.TITLE: hidden layer
PAGE24.TEXT1: This continues through the rest of the model.
PAGE24.TEXT2: The functions to use for each node in your model were chosen for you.

PAGE25.TITLE: output layer
PAGE25.TEXT1: Remember, the output layer gives the machine learning model's prediction.
PAGE25.TEXT2: Each node gives you the prediction for one of the buckets that you added to your training data.

PAGE26.TITLE: loss function
PAGE26.TEXT1: Remember, results from the output layer are compared with the correct answer, which shows how well the machine learning model is doing.

PAGE27.TITLE: back propagation
PAGE27.TEXT1: Remember that the error rate is used to go backwards through the layers and nudge the numbers associated with each of the lines and nodes.
PAGE27.TEXT2: Each weight and bias number is increased a little bit or decreased a little bit, depending on what would've made the error a little smaller.
PAGE27.TEXT3: This is how training works out the best numbers to use for each of the nodes and lines.

PAGE28.TITLE: epochs
PAGE28.TEXT1: One run-through of every training example you collected through the model is called an epoch.
PAGE28.TEXT2: Each time through, the weights for each node are nudged a little more, until hopefully the error rate for predictions are as low as they can be.
PAGE28.TEXT3: If you build your own machine learning model, you need to choose how many epochs you want to run.

PAGE29.TITLE: neural networks
PAGE29.TEXT1: I hope this simplified description gives you an idea what happens when you click on the "Train new machine learning model" button.
PAGE29.TEXT2: For an explanation of why this process works, try watching "How Machines Learn" by CGP Grey.

PROJECTS.TITLE: Project questions
PROJECTS.Q1: What is the difference between "images" and "images beta" projects?
PROJECTS.Q1-A-1: These can both be used to create the same sort of machine learning projects. The difference is where the models are created and stored.
PROJECTS.Q1-A-2: In "images" projects, machine learning models are trained on cloud servers using an online service called Watson Visual Recognition.
PROJECTS.Q1-A-3: In "images beta" projects, machine learning models are trained on the student's own computer, in the web browser.
PROJECTS.Q1-A-5: It can be used for projects in Scratch, App Inventor, or Python.
PROJECTS.Q1-A-6: It doesn't matter if your computer is slow, as the model is trained in the cloud.
PROJECTS.Q1-A-7: It can create models that are more accurate, particularly when using a small number of training examples.
PROJECTS.Q1-A-8: But, it takes several minutes to train while you wait for your turn on the cloud server, and (for unmanaged classes) requires a Watson API key from IBM Cloud.
PROJECTS.Q1-A-9: "images beta" is good because:
PROJECTS.Q1-A-10: It can be much quicker to train, because it starts training immediately without waiting for a turn on the cloud server.
PROJECTS.Q1-A-11: It doesn't require any IBM Cloud API keys (for unmanaged classes).
PROJECTS.Q1-A-12: Models do not need to be automatically deleted.
PROJECTS.Q1-A-13: But, it can only be used for Scratch projects, and requires the student to be using a reasonably fast computer.
PROJECTS.Q1-A-14: Training in the browser is described as a beta because it is a new feature on the site, and may still have problems with some operating systems or web browsers. If you encounter errors, please report these in the ML for Kids forum.
PROJECTS.Q2: How can you change an "images" project to be an "images beta" project (and vice versa)?
PROJECTS.Q2-A-1: You can change between the two modes from the "Learn & Test" page for your project.
PROJECTS.Q2-A-2: The link to do this is in top-right of the page.
PROJECTS.Q2-A-3: Any existing machine learning models for the project will be deleted if this is done.
PROJECTS.Q2-A-4: The Scratch blocks for image projects work differently for the two different modes, so if you have a Scratch window open when you do this, you will need to refresh the page so that the Scratch extension can be updated.

SCRATCH.TITLE: Frågor om Scratch
SCRATCH.Q1: Jag vet inte hur jag får Scratch att funka
SCRATCH.Q1-A-1: Maskininlärning för barn använder Scratch 2. Scratch behöver Adobe Flash för att fungera, så du behöver använda ett operativsystem och en webbläsare som fungerar med Flash (så det betyder inga iPads för tillfället, ledsen).
SCRATCH.Q1-A-2: Om du är osäker på hur man aktiverar Flash kan du ladda ner ett dokument med några tips om hur man får Scratch att fungera.
SCRATCH.Q2: "Ladda projekt"- och "Spara projekt"-menyerna i Scratch fungerar inte
SCRATCH.Q2-A-1: Om du använder Safari på macOS och Scratch-menyerna "Arkiv -> Ladda projekt" och "Arkiv -> Spara projekt" inte fungerar, kan det bero på att du kör i säkert läge
SCRATCH.Q2-A-2: Följ instruktionerna här för att se hur du kollar och fixar detta.
SCRATCH.Q3: Klassifieringsblock för maskininlärning fungerar inte i Scratch
SCRATCH.Q3-A-1: Emellanåt kan Scratch-blocken för din maskininlärningsmodell förlora anslutningen till servern. När det händer kommer de att sluta ge svar.
SCRATCH.Q3-A-2: Du kan kontrollera om det här har hänt genom att använda det färgade statusljuset i "Fler block"-paletten.
SCRATCH.Q3-A-3: Om statusljuset bredvid maskininlärningsblocken i Scratch är rött, betyder det vanligtvis att något är fel. Det kan vara ett tillfälligt problem. Försök spara ditt projekt (använd 'Arkiv' -> 'Spara projekt'), och ladda sedan om din webbläsarfönstret. Om statusljuset blir grönt efter att sidan laddats om, kan du öppna ditt projekt (med 'Arkiv' -> 'Öppna projekt') för att fortsätta där du slutade.
SCRATCH.Q3-A-4: Om statusljuset fortfarande är rött efter att sidan laddats om, så är det troligtvis något fel med maskininlärningsmodellen. Försök att gå till "Lär & testa"-sidan för projektet, där alla felmeddelanden för din modell finns.
SCRATCH.Q3-A-5: Om statusljuset bredvid dina maskininlärningsblock i Scratch är grönt så borde blocken fungera. Om du inte får de svar som du förväntar dig från dem, försök gå till "Lär & testa"-sidan och kontrollera vilka resultat din modell ger.
SCRATCH.Q5: Kan jag använda vilken version av Scratch som helst?
SCRATCH.Q5-A-1: Du måste använda Scratch-versionen som är tillgänglig på webbsidan Maskininlärning för barn. Den kan startas genom att klicka på Scratch-knappen (eller Scratch 3-knappen) från din projektsida.
SCRATCH.Q6: Scratch 3 is only saving projects to the 'Downloads' folder
SCRATCH.Q6-A-1: When you click 'File' -> 'Save to your computer' in Scratch 3, your Scratch project is saved to your computer.
SCRATCH.Q6-A-2: Some teachers reported a problem that this saved to the Downloads folder, on a computer where students don't have access in Windows to the Downloads folder. The result was that students were not able to access their saved projects.
SCRATCH.Q6-A-3: If you have this problem, you need to look in your web browser settings for a setting like 'Ask where to save each file before downloading'. If you enable that, your students will be able to choose where their projects are saved.

TRAININGUI.TITLE: Problem med träningsinterfacet
TRAININGUI.Q1: Det går inte att dra bilder till träningsbehållare (för bildprojekt)
TRAININGUI.Q1-A-1: Det går inte att dra bilder till träningsbehållare om du använder Internet Explorer.
TRAININGUI.Q1-A-2: Jag beklagar detta. Om du kan använda en annan webbläsare som Firefox eller Chrome, så gör gärna det. Annars kan du klicka på "www"-knappen och klistra in träningsbildernas URL:er istället.

MODELS.TITLE: Fel med att träna maskininlärningsmodeller
MODELS.Q1: "Inga uppgifter för Watson har ställts in"
MODELS.Q1-A-1: Maskininlärningsmodeller i verktyget skapas med IBM:s Watson-API:er.
MODELS.Q1-A-2: Om du har ett "ohanterat" klasskonto så behöver din lärare eller handledare tillhandahålla uppgifter för Watsons API från IBM Cloud för att detta ska fungera. Steg-för-steg-instruktioner för hur de kan göra det finns i "Kom igång"-dokumentet högst upp på den här sidan.
MODELS.Q2: "Uppgifter för Watson som används av din klass avvisades"
MODELS.Q2-A-1: Maskininlärningsmodeller i verktyget skapas med IBM:s Watson-API:er.
MODELS.Q2-A-2: Om du har ett "ohanterat" klasskonto så behöver din lärare eller handledare tillhandahålla uppgifter för Watsons API från IBM Cloud för att detta ska fungera, (vilket beskrivs i "Kom igång"-dokumentet högst upp på den här sidan).
MODELS.Q2-A-3: Men de uppgifter som har lagts in fungerar inte nu. Den troligaste orsaken är att uppgifterna har raderats från IBM Cloud efter att de har lagt till. Om det inte är fallet behöver läraren eller handledaren som lade till Watson-uppgifterna gå tillbaka till panelen för IBM Cloud och kontrollera statusen på tjänsterna Watson Assistant eller Visual Recognition som de skapat.
MODELS.Q3: "Watson Assistants API-nycklar har inget tillgängligt workspace"
MODELS.Q3-A-1: Maskininlärningsmodeller i verktyget skapas med IBM:s Watson-API:er.
MODELS.Q3-A-2: Uppgifter för Watson Assistant som skapas av lärare har en begränsning för antalet maskininlärningsmodeller som de kan användas för. Det här visas i IBM Cloud:s användargränssnitt där uppgifterna skapades, och där de kallas "workspaces".
MODELS.Q3-A-3: Om denna begränsning överskrids kommer försök att träna nya maskininlärningsmodeller att misslyckas, och det här meddelandet kommer att visas:
MODELS.Q3-A-4: Din klass har redan skapat det maximala tillåtna antalet modeller. Vänligen informera din lärare eller handledare att "Watson Assistants API-nycklar inte har något tillgängligt workspace".
MODELS.Q3-A-5: Om en elev som har en framgångsrikt tränad modell raderar sin modell, kommer det att frigöra ett workspace som kan användas av en annan elev.
MODELS.Q3-A-6: Ett sätt att undvika det här felet i fortsättningen kan vara mindre klasser. Om det är färre elever än antalet workspaces som stöds av Watson Assistants begränsningar, så kommer begränsningen inte att nås.
MODELS.Q3-A-7: Ett annat sätt att undvika detta fel är att lägga till ytterligare API-nycklar för Watson Assistant till klassen, eller att använda en Watson Assistant-instans med en "plan" som har mindre begränsningar.
MODELS.Q4: "API-nycklar för Watson Visual Recognition har inga fler klassificerare tillgängliga"
MODELS.Q4-A-1: Maskininlärningsmodeller i verktyget skapas med IBM:s Watson-API:er.
MODELS.Q4-A-2: Uppgifter för Watson Visual Recognition skapade av lärare har en begränsning för antalet maskininlärningsmodeller som de kan användas för att skapa. Det här visas i IBM Cloud:s användargränssnitt där uppgifterna skapades, och där de kallas "custom classifiers".
MODELS.Q4-A-3: Om denna begränsning överskrids kommer försök att träna nya maskininlärningsmodeller att misslyckas, och det här meddelandet kommer att visas:
MODELS.Q4-A-4: Din klass har redan skapat det maximala tillåtna antalet modeller. Vänligen informera din lärare eller handledare att "API-nycklarna för Watson Visual Recognition inte har fler klassificerare tillgängliga".
MODELS.Q4-A-5: Om en elev som har en framgångsrikt tränad modell raderar sin modell, kommer det att frigöra en custom classifier som kan användas av en annan elev.
MODELS.Q4-A-6: Ett sätt att undvika det här felet i fortsättningen kan vara mindre klasser. Om det är färre elever än antalet custom classifiers som stöds av Watson Visual Recognition-uppgifterna, så kommer begränsningen inte att nås.
MODELS.Q4-A-7: Ett annat sätt att undvika detta fel är att lägga till ytterligare API-nycklar för Watson Visual Recognition till klassen, eller att använda en Watson Visual Recognition-instans med en "plan" som har mindre begränsningar.
MODELS.Q5: "Watson ... begränsar för närvarande anropsfrekvensen för sin API-nyckel"
MODELS.Q5-A-1: Maskininlärningsmodeller i verktyget skapas med IBM:s Watson-API:er.
MODELS.Q5-A-2: Om du har ett "ohanterat" klasskonto så behöver din lärare eller handledare tillhandahålla uppgifter för Watsons API från IBM Cloud för att detta ska fungera.
MODELS.Q5-A-3: Om gratiskonton skapas, kommer det att finnas en begränsad anropsfrekvens ("rate limiting") för nya maskininlärningsmodeller. Vid normal användning kommer detta inte att påverka klassen. Men om elever får ett fel av typen "inget tillgängligt workspace" eller "inga fler klassificerare tillgängliga" (som beskrivs ovan) men fortsätter att klicka på knappen "Träna en ny maskininlärningsmodell" flera gånger per sekund i flera minuter, kommer begränsningen att inträda.
MODELS.Q5-A-4: Ett sånt här meddelande kommer att visas för elever i det här fallet:
MODELS.Q5-A-5: Din klass gör för många anrop för att skapa maskininlärningsmodeller allt för ofta. Var snäll och sluta nu och informera din lärare eller handledare att "Watson Assistant-tjänsten begränsar anropsfrekvensen för API-nyckeln just nu"
MODELS.Q5-A-6: Begränsningen i anropsfrekvens är inte skapad av, och kontrolleras inte av webbsajten Maskininlärning för barn. Den är vanligtvis tillfällig och löses bäst genom att vänta en kort stund.
MODELS.Q5-A-7: Om elever klickar på knappen "Träna en ny maskininlärningsmodell" flertalet gånger och får meddelandet "inget tillgängligt workspace" eller "inga fler klassificerare tillgängliga" (som beskrivs ovan), så bör de vara medvetna om att klicka på knappen kontinuerligt inte kommer att lösa problemet, utan det kommer i själva verket förvärra situationen för resten av klassen.
MODELS.Q6: Jag har väntat på att en modell ska tränas klart i en evighet!
MODELS.Q6-A-2: Sidan bör kontrollera maskininlärningsmodellens status var 30:e sekund, men i väldigt sällsynta fall slutar den kolla, så det kan hända att du väntar på modellen när den i själva verket är klar.
MODELS.Q6-A-3: Om det har tagit fler än ett par minuter kan det vara värt att testa att uppdatera / ladda om sidan.
MODELS.Q6-A-4: Om det har tagit fler än tio minuter, kan det vara värt att fundera på att starta om (klicka på Avbryt-knappen och klicka sedan på knappen för att träna en ny maskininlärningsmodell igen).
MODELS.Q7: "Your class is sharing Watson API keys ... there are currently none available"
MODELS.Q7-A-1: Machine learning models in the tool are created using IBM Watson APIs.
MODELS.Q7-A-2: If you have a "managed" class account, this means your class is sharing these keys with many other schools.
MODELS.Q7-A-3: There are normally enough for all schools, but if it is very busy and all of the available API keys are currently in use, attempts to train new machine learning models will fail, and this message will be displayed:
MODELS.Q7-A-4: Your class is sharing Watson Assistant / Visual Recognition "API keys" with many other schools, and unfortunately there are currently none available. Please let your teacher or group leader know that you will have to train your machine learning model later
MODELS.Q7-A-5: If a student who has a successfully trained model then deletes their model, this will free up a workspace for use by another student.
MODELS.Q7-A-6: The best thing to do is to try again later, after other students have deleted their machine learning models and API keys are available again. Your training data will still be safe until then.
MODELS.Q7-A-7: Another way to avoid this error is for your class to create an "unmanaged" class account, which is where a teacher creates their own Watson "API keys" that can be dedicated only for use by their own class.

TEACHERUI.TITLE: Problem med Lärare-/Admin-gränssnitt
TEACHERUI.Q2: Elevkonton saknas i listan på lärarens sida
TEACHERUI.Q2-A-1: Användarhantering i Maskininlärning för barn tillhandahålls genom tredjepartstjänsten Auth0.
TEACHERUI.Q2-A-2: Emellanåt kan listan med elever som Auth0 ger bli lite inaktuell, och misslyckas med att presentera elever som nyligen har skapats (eller på motsvarande sätt fortfarande visa elever som nyligen har raderats).
TEACHERUI.Q2-A-3: I dessa fall har elever blivit skapade (eller raderade) framgångsrikt och det är bara listan med elever som visas som inte reflekterar nyliga uppdateringar.
TEACHERUI.Q2-A-4: Auth0 kommer normalt att rapportera sådana incidenter på sin statussida som "user indexing delays" eller problem med deras Sök-API.
TEACHERUI.Q2-A-5: Det bästa man kan göra i de här fallen är att vänta på att Auth0:s indexering hinner ikapp.
TEACHERUI.Q4-A-1: Det här var en funktion som efterfrågades av skolor när Maskininlärning för barn först utvecklades. Det kom från det faktum att det finns en begränsning för hur många maskininlärningsmodeller en klass kan ha samtidigt, och som ett sätt att göra det enkelt att hantera denna begränsning.
TEACHERUI.Q4-A-2: Istället för att kräva att elever ska rensa upp efter en lektion och radera sina modeller (för att tillåta att nästa klass att kunna skapa modeller), kan verktyget automatiskt rensa upp genom att radera modellerna efter att lektionen är över. Det gör det enkelt att köra nästa lektion, och nästa efter det, utan manuella rensningar mellan.
TEACHERUI.Q4-A-3: Tidsgränsen innan modellerna raderas kan ställas in. I en skola där lektionerna är 1 eller 2 timmar långa, kan det vara förnuftigt att radera dem efter 2 timmar. För en kodningsträff en gång i veckan kan sex dagar vara mer lämpligt för att säkerställa att modellerna är rensade innan varje ny träff.
TEACHERUI.Q4-A-4: För att kontrollera tidsgränsen för din klass, besök Begränsningar-sektionen på din lärarsida..
TEACHERUI.Q4-A-6: Obs: Endast maskininlärningsmodeller raderas automatiskt, inte träningsdatan som användes för att skapa dem. Så om en modell raderas automatiskt för ett projekt som en elev fortfarande jobbar på, kan hen alltid bara klicka på "Träna"-knappen igen för att skapa modellen igen.

ACCOUNTISSUES.TITLE: Kontoproblem
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q1: Vad är skillnaden mellan att skapa ett konto och att använda "Testa nu"?
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q1-A-1: Att använda "Testa nu" innebär att man inte behöver logga in eller skapa ett konto. Det finns inga lösenord elever behöver komma ihåg och lärare behöver inte ange personlig information. Det sparar också tid för lärare att behöva hantera studentkonton.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q1-A-2: Men att skapa ett konto aktiverar ytterligare funktioner. Elever kan spara sitt arbete och gå tillbaka till det senare under lektionen. De kan arbeta med ett projekt tillsammans med andra elever i sin klass. De kan logga in hemifrån och visa sin familj vad de har gjort.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q1-A-3: En sammanfattning av skillnaderna visas nedan:
ACCOUNTISSUES.TRAINMODELS: Träna maskininlärningsmodeller för att känna igen...
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q2: Jag har skapat ett klasskonto men mitt lärar-login fungerar inte
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q2-A-1: Du måste verifiera din e-postadress innan du kan logga in.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q2-A-2: När du skapade ditt klasskonto, skickades ett mejl till e-postadressen du angav, med en länk att klicka på. Om du klickar på den länken kommer din e-postadress att verifieras och klasskontot kommer att aktiveras. Du bör kunna logga in nu.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q2-A-3: Om du inte har sett verifieringsmejlet än, kontrollera att det inte hamnat i din skräpkorg.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q2-A-4: Om du fortfarande inte kan hitta det, informera mig (på engelska) så ska jag försöka hjälpa dig.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q3-A-2: Elever kan inte radera sina egna konton.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q3-A-3: En lärare kan radera ett elevkonto närsomhelst genom att besöka "Lärare"-sidan och klicka på "Radera studentkonto"-knappen bredvid studentkontot du vill radera.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q3-A-4: Detta kommer att radera all information som lagras om eleven och alla dennes projekt och maskininlärningsmodeller.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q3-A-7: Att radera ett lärarkonto kommer att radera hela klassen och alla elevkonton i den. Det kan inte ångras.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q3-A-8: Detta kan göras genom att klicka på "Radera klass"-knappen i sektionen för avancerade inställningar på din Lärarsida
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4-A-2: I store the username and email address that you provide when you create the account, so that I can keep in touch with you.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4-A-4: I store the usernames for student accounts, so that I can let them log in. I have no email addresses or contact details for students. I have no other personally identifying information about students.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4-A-5: I also recommend that students are given generic usernames (e.g. student1) so that students are not identifiable outside of their school or coding group.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4-A-6: General information stored about all accounts
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4-A-7: User management for Machine Learning for Kids is implemented using the third party service, Auth0. They store the IP address that you last logged into Machine Learning for Kids from, and the type of browser you used. I've never found a reason to use that, but it is stored if I did want to go and look for it.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4-A-8: Errors that happen in the web browser are captured using the third party service, Sentry. If something goes wrong, it will capture information about the error, including your username, IP address, type of browser you were using, and a technical description of what went wrong.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4-A-9: I use Google Analytics so that I know how many users visit Machine Learning for Kids each day. Although it captures information such as geographic location and browser type, this is only ever displayed to me in an anonymised aggregate way.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q5: What happens to training data created by students?
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q5-A-1: A step in all machine learning projects that students make using this site is to create or collect training examples. For text projects, this can mean typing in short text passages. For image projects, this can means drawing pictures onto an on-screen canvas or taking photos using the webcam. For numbers projects, this means typing in sets of numbers
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q5-A-2: All of these training examples are stored in a PostgreSQL database hosted on IBM Cloud, in Dallas in the United States. As the database administrator, I have access to all of these training examples for all student projects, however I do not use it for any other purposes other than enabling students to access and work on their own projects. I do not publish the training data (either publicly or to individuals or third parties) or otherwise share it, with the two exceptions of submitting it to IBM Watson APIs described below.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q5-A-3: Machine learning models for text projects are created using the IBM Watson Assistant cloud service, which means when students train a model, a copy of the training examples that they have entered will be submitted to IBM Watson. (The location of this cloud service is something that teachers choose when creating API keys.) IBM Watson does not use these training examples for any other purposes. This is because Machine Learning for Kids requests an opt-out for student training examples being used by IBM to improve the service, as described in the Watson documentation.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q5-A-4: Machine learning models for images projects are created using the IBM Visual Recognition cloud service, which means when students train a model, a copy of their training images will be uploaded to IBM Watson. (The location of this cloud service is something that teachers choose when creating API keys.) IBM Watson does not use these training examples for any other purposes. This is because Machine Learning for Kids requests an opt-out for student training examples being used by IBM to improve the service, as described in the Watson documentation.
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q5-A-5: IBM Watson provides some general guidance for sharing training data with their services, which also apply to training data created and collected in Machine Learning for Kids. Specifically, students should be advised not to include personally identifiable information in the examples that they collect.

APIKEYSGUIDE.TITLE: Guide to IBM Cloud

INTRO.INTRO_1: Teachers / parents / code club-leaders with unmanaged class accounts need to provide 'API Keys' from IBM Cloud. These are secret codes that provide access to the artificial intelligence technology that will power student projects.
INTRO.INTRO_2: Text projects need a 'Watson Assistant' API Key. Image projects need a 'Visual Recognition' API Key. (Numbers and Sound projects don't require API Keys).
INTRO.INTRO_3: You will need to create an account on IBM Cloud to be able to create these codes. It is free to create an account, and there are no charges for 'Lite' API Keys.

APIKEYSGUIDE.EXPLANATION: Download a step-by-step guide for how to create API Keys on IBM Cloud

INTRO.INTRO_1: Machine Learning for Kids provides pre-trained models you can use in your projects. Real-world machine learning projects often use models already trained by other people. There are lots of well-trained models that are freely available, and these are useful when you don't have time to collect the amount of training data needed to train your own.

HOWTO.TITLE: How to use
HOWTO.INTRO: Click on the button to go to Scratch.
HOWTO.HOW_1: Go to the version of Scratch 3 available from Machine Learning for Kids.
HOWTO.HOW_2: Pre-trained models are available from the Extensions panel. Click on the blue extensions button in the bottom-left of the Scratch window to find them, then click on the one you want to add to your project.
HOWTO.HOW_3: The blocks for the pre-trained model will be added to the Scratch toolbox.

SPEECHTOTEXT.TITLE: Speech to text
SPEECHTOTEXT.SPEECH_1: This model can be used to recognize speech recorded through your microphone.
SPEECHTOTEXT.SPEECH_2: It gives you a block you can use to record some audio and then give you the text that it recognized, and a block that you can tell it to listen out for a particular word or phrase.
SPEECHTOTEXT.SPEECH_3: It uses the speech recognition capability that comes with Google Chrome, so the ML model that you'll be using comes from Google. (It also means that you can only use this model if you're using the Google Chrome web browser, sorry!)

FACEAPI.TITLE: Face detection
FACEAPI.FACE_1: This model can be used to recognize your face in the video feed from your webcam.
FACEAPI.FACE_2: It gives you blocks that will find the x,y coordinates of your eyes, nose and mouth.
FACEAPI.FACE_3: This uses a top-down technique - it starts by looking for something that looks like a face in the picture. Once it has found that, it tries to identify facial features in that area. The machine learning model is based on MobileNet (a ML model designed for mobile devices, so it doesn't need much computing power).
FACEAPI.FACE_4: The training data used for this model came from a set known as WIDER FACE.

POSENET.TITLE: Pose detection
POSENET.POSE_1: This model can be used to recognize your pose in the video feed from your webcam.
POSENET.POSE_2: It gives you blocks that will find the x,y coordinates of different parts of your body, like shoulders, elbows, wrists, knees, and ankles.
POSENET.POSE_3: This uses a bottom-up technique - looking for human body key points (like shoulders, elbows, knees, etc.) and then grouping them to identify a person and the pose that they're in. The technique is based on MobileNet (a ML model designed for mobile devices, so it doesn't need much computing power).
POSENET.POSE_4: The training data used for this model came from a set known as Common Objects in Context (COCO).

TOXICITY.TITLE: Toxicity
TOXICITY.TOXICITY_1: This model can be used to recognize whether text contains toxic content.
TOXICITY.TOXICITY_2: It gives you blocks that will predict the percentage probability that some provided text contains toxic content such as threatening language, insults, obscenities, or identity-based hate.
TOXICITY.TOXICITY_3: The training data used for this model came from two-million user-generated comments posted on news articles.

IDEAS.IDEAS_1: Are there other machine learning models you would like to be able to use in your Scratch projects?
IDEAS.IDEAS_2: Let me know by asking in the ML for Kids forum.

TENSORFLOW.TITLE: TensorFlow
TENSORFLOW.TF_1: TensorFlow is a toolkit for training and running machine learning models.
TENSORFLOW.TF_2: If you know how to create your own machine learning model with TensorFlow, click the button above to use it in Scratch.
TENSORFLOW.TF_3: You can build your own model, using programming languages like Python.
TENSORFLOW.TF_4: Or you can use tools like Teachable Machine to easily train a TensorFlow model, and then make something with it in Scratch here.
TENSORFLOW.TF_5: (Only image classifiers are supported today, but support for more types of machine learning model is coming soon!)
